comment._content: The Spy Who Came In From The Cold Werner Van Horn, an alleged German army reservist, arrived by train in Vanceboro, Maine (population 147 at the 2000 census) on a Saturday night from New York, and put up at a local hotel. He had intended to escape into Canada after blowing up the international railroad bridge the following night, but the February night was so cold (28° below zero F) (–33° C) that one of his hands and one foot were badly frozen, and his clothing was encrusted with ice. So he went back to the hotel in Vanceboro, He was arrested the following morning at 7:00am by a Deputy sheriff and a Maine Central Railroad officer. It seems the German was the only stranger in Vanceboro. — The New York Times
